tags: source: mama mia here we go again
summary: When Arya hears about Gendry's trip past the Wall.
body:
When Arya hears about Gendry’s trip past the Wall.

Arya: What are you doing!?

Gendry: If you love someone, you’re willing to die for them.

Arya: Yeah but you don’t have to. That’s an important distinction!

summary: Would naming Arya heir to Robb be such a bad idea if she had gotten back to them in time? She would have had the counsel of...
question: Would naming Arya heir to Robb be such a bad idea if she had gotten back to them in time? She would have had the counsel of Catelyn and Brynden Blackfish (who would be looking out for her best interest) and she could be matched with Wylis Manderly to have a powerful Northern ally. Do you think there is any chance Stoneheart crowns Arya as “Queen in the North” with Robb’s crown?
answer:
Crowning Arya invites conflict from a pro-Sansa faction (at the time of Robb writing his will, that looked a lot like the Lannisters), as well as creates circumstances where there could be an ugly fight over the regency. Arya’s still a child in the eyes of Westeros, and a girl to boot; Catelyn’s actions in freeing Jaime would likely render her an unsuitable regent in the eyes of many Northerners; Brynden’s no Northman and hasn’t even lived there. Also, Wylis Manderly is married. Wendel Manderly is not, but he’s also round about thirty years older than Arya. (Catelyn VIII, AGoT - Catelyn notes that Wyman Manderly’s “boys” are both older than her.)

Robb does not want the Balon situation to happen in the North if he dies, and naming Arya is a good way to get the Balon situation. By contrast, “I want my legitimised (technically) adult half brother to inherit ahead of my sisters” provides a nice clear precedent as well as adult male leadership more broadly acceptable for the problems facing the realm.

And no, I doubt Lady Stoneheart crowns Arya. Lady Stoneheart has no plans beyond killing everyone who hurt her in life. She may give Arya the crown to take back to Winterfell, but that’s it.

reblog.comment:
Crowning Arya invites conflict from a pro-Sansa faction (at the time of Robb writing his will, that looked a lot like the Lannisters), as well as creates circumstances where there could be an ugly fight over the regency. Arya’s still a child in the eyes of Westeros, and a girl to boot; Catelyn’s actions in freeing Jaime would likely render her an unsuitable regent in the eyes of many Northerners; Brynden’s no Northman and hasn’t even lived there. Also, Wylis Manderly is married. Wendel Manderly is not, but he’s also round about thirty years older than Arya. (Catelyn VIII, AGoT - Catelyn notes that Wyman Manderly’s “boys” are both older than her.)

Robb does not want the Balon situation to happen in the North if he dies, and naming Arya is a good way to get the Balon situation. By contrast, “I want my legitimised (technically) adult half brother to inherit ahead of my sisters” provides a nice clear precedent as well as adult male leadership more broadly acceptable for the problems facing the realm.

And no, I doubt Lady Stoneheart crowns Arya. Lady Stoneheart has no plans beyond killing everyone who hurt her in life. She may give Arya the crown to take back to Winterfell, but that’s it.

trail.content_raw:
Crowning Arya invites conflict from a pro-Sansa faction (at the time of Robb writing his will, that looked a lot like the Lannisters), as well as creates circumstances where there could be an ugly fight over the regency. Arya’s still a child in the eyes of Westeros, and a girl to boot; Catelyn’s actions in freeing Jaime would likely render her an unsuitable regent in the eyes of many Northerners; Brynden’s no Northman and hasn’t even lived there. Also, Wylis Manderly is married. Wendel Manderly is not, but he’s also round about thirty years older than Arya. (Catelyn VIII, AGoT - Catelyn notes that Wyman Manderly’s “boys” are both older than her.)

Robb does not want the Balon situation to happen in the North if he dies, and naming Arya is a good way to get the Balon situation. By contrast, “I want my legitimised (technically) adult half brother to inherit ahead of my sisters” provides a nice clear precedent as well as adult male leadership more broadly acceptable for the problems facing the realm.

And no, I doubt Lady Stoneheart crowns Arya. Lady Stoneheart has no plans beyond killing everyone who hurt her in life. She may give Arya the crown to take back to Winterfell, but that’s it.
trail.content:
Crowning Arya invites conflict from a pro-Sansa faction (at the time of Robb writing his will, that looked a lot like the Lannisters), as well as creates circumstances where there could be an ugly fight over the regency. Arya’s still a child in the eyes of Westeros, and a girl to boot; Catelyn’s actions in freeing Jaime would likely render her an unsuitable regent in the eyes of many Northerners; Brynden’s no Northman and hasn’t even lived there. Also, Wylis Manderly is married. Wendel Manderly is not, but he’s also round about thirty years older than Arya. (Catelyn VIII, AGoT - Catelyn notes that Wyman Manderly’s “boys” are both older than her.)

Robb does not want the Balon situation to happen in the North if he dies, and naming Arya is a good way to get the Balon situation. By contrast, “I want my legitimised (technically) adult half brother to inherit ahead of my sisters” provides a nice clear precedent as well as adult male leadership more broadly acceptable for the problems facing the realm.

And no, I doubt Lady Stoneheart crowns Arya. Lady Stoneheart has no plans beyond killing everyone who hurt her in life. She may give Arya the crown to take back to Winterfell, but that’s it.

tags: THIS MAKES ZERO SENSE BUT ALSO SANSA WOULD
imagine theyre breaking into the red keep to kill cersei
summary:
Sansa: lets do ‘get help’
Arya: what?
Sansa: ‘get help’
Arya: no
Sansa: come on, you love it
Arya: I hate it
Sansa: it’s great....
body:
Sansa: lets do ‘get help’

Arya: what?

Sansa: ‘get help’

Arya: no

Sansa: come on, you love it

Arya: I hate it

Sansa: it’s great. It works everytime

Arya: it’s humiliating

Sansa: do you have a better plan?

Arya: no

Sansa: we’re doing it

Arya: we are not doing ‘get help’

*several minutes later*

Sansa, dragging Arya: Get help! Please! My sister is dying! Get help! Help her!

Sansa: *throws Arya at a few guards, knocking them over*

Sansa: classic!

Arya, getting up: I still hate it. It’s humiliating

Sansa: not for me, it’s not

tags: A Song of Ice and Fire
summary: Another reason to ship Sansan: Arya would be the worst/best sister in law to Sandor. In barbecue meetings, she'd ask Sansa "What...
body: Another reason to ship Sansan: Arya would be the worst/best sister in law to Sandor. In barbecue meetings, she’d ask Sansa “What did you even see in that guy?” then slap him in the butt and tell him to move over the grill because he can’t cook for shit. He would called her a brat and they would fight for the fork while Sansa rolls her eyes.

reblog.comment: Another reason to ship Sansan: Arya would be the worst/best sister in law to Sandor. In barbecue meetings, she’d ask Sansa “What did you even see in that guy?” then slap him in the butt and tell him to move over the grill because he can’t cook for shit. He would called her a brat and they would fight for the fork while Sansa rolls her eyes.

In barbecue meetings, she’d ask Sansa “What did you even see in that guy?” then slap him in the butt and tell him to move over the grill because he can’t cook for shit. He would called her a brat and they would fight for the fork while Sansa rolls her eyes.

summary:
Inktober Catch Up Part 2! Another process video, this time of this image.
These two are Sansa and Arya from my Staying Together...
body:
Inktober Catch Up Part 2! Another process video, this time of this image.

These two are Sansa and Arya from my Staying Together AU, where they have to work as small folk. Day 5 of the Inktober Prompts was “chicken”, so here’s Sansa feeding and distracting the chickens while Arya gets the eggs.

tags: you guys sick of this shit yet?
too bad i have several more archetype/symbolism books on my to read list lol
summary:
more on arya stark + “goddesses in every woman” by jean shinoda bolen: 



It helps to realize that death and rebirth, in myth...
body:
more on arya stark + “goddesses in every woman” by jean shinoda bolen:

It helps to realize that death and rebirth, in myth and dreams, are metaphors for loss, depression, and recovery. In retrospect, many such dark periods turn out to be rites of passage, a time of suffering through which a woman has learned something of value, and has grown.

this is the way arya’s arc should be viewed but never is. people get caught up in the assassin aspect and the show is downright gimmicky (empty) about it but the whole storyline is literally a struggle to overcome depression and trauma. when experiencing loss it can feel like losing yourself or as if you’re gone. as if you’re no one without those you cared for. thats what arya is going through. thats what the “no one” and faces thing in the hob&w truly represents. she is at risk of losing herself to grief. when she lost her family and home she feels as if she died too. she’s in so much pain. but arya will be reborn. she can recover and heal and grow. 

Similarly, the heroine’s journey is an individuation quest. Traveling this path, the heroine may find, lose, and rediscover what has meaning to her, until she holds on to these values in all kinds of circumstances that test her. She may repeatedly encounter whatever threatens to overcome her, until finally the danger of losing her selfhood is over.

what has meaning to arya is her pack. she was set on that path early in her story when ned told her “the lone wolf dies but the pack survives” but then she lost her pack as she was thrown out into the world without them. then she found it again in gendry and hot pie. only to lose it again when they left. and lose it again and again when her entire family was (seemingly) killed. which “threatens to overcome her” and endangers arya’s “selfhood” but eventually she will find her pack and herself and nothing will be able to take either from her. 

Note that after proving her courage and competency, the heroine does not go riding off into the sunset by herself, like the archetypal cowboy hero. Nor is she cast in the mold of the conquering hero. Union, reunion, and home are where her journey ends.

i almost screamed when i read this lol. if everyone would look back at what ive been preaching! arya’s journey will not end with her alone and cast off. she has struggled too hard against that. in the end she will find the identity, family, and home that she’s been looking for.

reblog.comment:

trail.content_raw:
more on arya stark + “goddesses in every woman” by jean shinoda bolen:

It helps to realize that death and rebirth, in myth and dreams, are metaphors for loss, depression, and recovery. In retrospect, many such dark periods turn out to be rites of passage, a time of suffering through which a woman has learned something of value, and has grown.

this is the way arya’s arc should be viewed but never is. people get caught up in the assassin aspect and the show is downright gimmicky (empty) about it but the whole storyline is literally a struggle to overcome depression and trauma. when experiencing loss it can feel like losing yourself or as if you’re gone. as if you’re no one without those you cared for. thats what arya is going through. thats what the “no one” and faces thing in the hob&w truly represents. she is at risk of losing herself to grief. when she lost her family and home she feels as if she died too. she’s in so much pain. but arya will be reborn. she can recover and heal and grow. 

Similarly, the heroine’s journey is an individuation quest. Traveling this path, the heroine may find, lose, and rediscover what has meaning to her, until she holds on to these values in all kinds of circumstances that test her. She may repeatedly encounter whatever threatens to overcome her, until finally the danger of losing her selfhood is over.

what has meaning to arya is her pack. she was set on that path early in her story when ned told her “the lone wolf dies but the pack survives” but then she lost her pack as she was thrown out into the world without them. then she found it again in gendry and hot pie. only to lose it again when they left. and lose it again and again when her entire family was (seemingly) killed. which “threatens to overcome her” and endangers arya’s “selfhood” but eventually she will find her pack and herself and nothing will be able to take either from her. 

Note that after proving her courage and competency, the heroine does not go riding off into the sunset by herself, like the archetypal cowboy hero. Nor is she cast in the mold of the conquering hero. Union, reunion, and home are where her journey ends.

i almost screamed when i read this lol. if everyone would look back at what ive been preaching! arya’s journey will not end with her alone and cast off. she has struggled too hard against that. in the end she will find the identity, family, and home that she’s been looking for.
